Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation in Engineering through Center-based Research

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) is one of the oldest and most prestigious fellowship programs for the National Science Foundation (NSF). The program's reputation derives from the high level of success achieved by students receiving the fellowship as well as those receiving honorable mention. As such, it is important to ensure that students from traditionally underrepresented groups in engineering are aware of the value and process of applying for graduate fellowships. Addressing access to advanced degrees is critical to the nation's ability to recruit and retain high achieving engineers and scientists within the U.S. STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) workforce. Formative issues for many GRFP applicants who are underrepresented in engineering include formal and informal training in scientific writing and communication, professional development training, and access to mentors and role models engaged in innovative research.

This workshop connects engineering and science students from underrepresented populations to a currently funded NSF Engineering Research Center. This project builds on a working hypothesis that underrepresented and women students motivated by researchers working on socially relevant, convergent research will build capacity to develop competitive fellowship applications. This hypothesis is tested through the development and delivery of a workshop that incorporates introductions to researchers, professional development, and informal training in scientific writing. This activity, led by a principal investigator from an HBCU, directly supports the NSF ERC goal of developing a culture that is diverse and inclusive.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) is one of the oldest and most prestigious fellowship programs for the National Science Foundation (NSF). The program's reputation derives from the high level of success achieved by students receiving the fellowship as well as those receiving honorable mention. As such, it is important to ensure that students from traditionally underrepresented groups in engineering are aware of the value and process of applying for graduate fellowships. Addressing access to advanced degrees is critical to the nation's ability to recruit and retain high achieving engineers and scientists within the U.S. STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) workforce. Formative issues for many GRFP applicants who are underrepresented in engineering include formal and informal training in scientific writing and communication, professional development training, and access to mentors and role models engaged in innovative research.

This NSF grant funded workshop connected engineering and science students from underrepresented populations to the funded NSF Engineering Research Center, Cell Manufacturing Technologies (CMAT) at Georgia Institute of Technology. This project builds on a working hypothesis that underrepresented and women students motivated by researchers working on socially relevant, convergent research will build capacity to develop competitive fellowship applications. This hypothesis was tested through the development and delivery of a workshop that incorporated introductions to researchers, professional development, and informal training in scientific writing. This activity, led by a principal investigator from an HBCU, directly supported the NSF ERC goal of developing a culture that is diverse and inclusive.

As a continuation of the funded project, during the fall of 2020 semester, four (4) Fort Valley State University students participated in a weekly mentorship program with the project PI and other participating faculty from FVSU to go on to careers in engineering. The students stated preferences in the areas of bio- and biomedical engineering, electrical engineering and nuclear engineering. These students also received monthly mentorship with a potential future ERC partner (Cell-Met ERC at Boston University). The students participated in a combination of face-to-face and virtual mentorship with faculty from FVSU and virtually (due to the pandemic) with a CellMet researcher (Dr. Helen Fawcett) from Boston University. Dr. Fawcett was able to fly to Atlanta and drive to the Fort Valley State University campus immediately prior to the University System of Georgia’s response to the COVID-19 pandemic in March of 2020 to meet with potential Cell-Met ERC student participants from Fort Valley State University. Faculty project participants throughout the duration of the project include:

Dr. Archie Williams, Chair and Professor, Department of Agricultural and Electrical Engineering Technology, Fort Valley State University

Dr. Washella Simmons, Chair and Associate Professor of English, Liberal Arts Studies Program, Fort Valley State University

Dr. Diane Byrd, Associate Professor of Psychology, Department of Behavioral Studies, Fort Valley State University

Dr. Erick Jones, Endowed Professor, Industrial Manufacturing and Systems Engineering Department, University of Texas Arlington

Dr. Michael Westrate, Assistant Professor, Dept. of History & Honors Program, Villanova University
